Do NOT include other goals. --> | nationalyears1 = 2002â2003 | nationalyears2 = 2003 | nationalyears3 = 2004â2005 | nationalyears4 = 2006â2008 | nationalyears5 = 2008â | nationalteam1 = [[France national under-17 football team|France U17]] | nationalteam2 = [[France national under-18 football team|France U18]] | nationalteam3 = [[France national under-19 football team|France U19]] | nationalteam4 = [[France national under-21 football team|France U21]] | nationalteam5 = [[France national football team|France]] | nationalcaps1 = 12 | nationalcaps2 = 4 | nationalcaps3 = 17 | nationalcaps4 = 18 | nationalcaps5 = 28 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | nationalgoals3 = 7 | nationalgoals4 = 4 | nationalgoals5 = 4 | club-update = 29 October 2011 | nationalteam-update = 29 March 2011 (UTC) }}
'''Yoann Miguel Gourcuff''' ({{IPA-fr|joan É¡uÊkyf}}; born 11 July 1986) is a [[List of France international footballers|French international footballer]] who currently plays for French club [[Olympique Lyonnais]] in [[Ligue 1]]. He operates mainly as an [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]], but can also be utilized as a [[Forward (association football)#Second striker|withdrawn striker]] and is described as a "playmaker of real quality" who "is an accomplished passer of the ball".<ref>{{Cite news|title=Yoann Gourcuff: The new Zidane? |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/yoann-gourcuff-the-new-zidane-1516832.html |work=The Independent |location=UK |date=27 January 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Yoann Gourcuff ESPN Profile |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/player/_/id/41561/yoann-gourcuff?cc=5901 |work=[[ESPN]] |date= |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> Gourcuff has been described by former [[France national football team|French international]] [[David Ginola]] as the best French player of his generation.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff is probably the most talented player of his generation |url=http://www.sport.co.uk/news/Football/45443/Gourcuff_is_probably_the_most_talented_player_of_his_generation.aspx |work=Sport.co.uk |date=19 October 2010 |accessdate=21 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Ginola: Gourcuff is the best in a generation |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=833711&sec=europe&cc=5901 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=19 October 2010 |accessdate=21 October 2010}}</ref> His playing style and ability have drawn comparisons to French legend [[Zinedine Zidane]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Yoann Gourcuff au TrophÃ©e Unfp |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NUnobSDsJk4 |publisher=YouTube |date=24 May 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref>
Gourcuff is the son of [[Christian Gourcuff]], the current manager of Ligue 1 club [[FC Lorient]], where Yoann began his career.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff par Gourcuff |url=http://www.gourcuffyoann.fr/327_gourcuff-par-gourcuff|work=Yoann Gourcuff |date=31 July 2008 |accessdate=12 August 2009 | language = French}}</ref> In 2001, he followed in his father's footsteps and joined [[Stade Rennais F.C.|Rennes]]. After progressing through the youth ranks and making the senior team, Gourcuff quickly became a fan favorite among supporters and his individual achievements soon led to interest from clubs abroad, which resulted in a move to Italian club [[A.C. Milan|AC Milan]].<ref name="monstersandcritics.com">{{Cite news|title=AC Milan sign French talent Gourcuff |url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/sport/soccer/article_1174813.php/Report_AC_Milan_sign_French_talent_Gourcuff |work=Monsters and Critics |date=22 June 2006 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref> Gourcuff achieved many club honours despite not being able to break into the starting eleven, which resulted in the player being sent on loan to Ligue 1 club Bordeaux in his home country of France.<ref name="m.espn.go.com">{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff joins Bordeaux on loan from Milan |url=http://m.espn.go.com/soccer/story?storyId=542217&teamId=159&lang= |work=[[ESPN]] |date=3 June 2008 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref> Following a successful season, in which Bordeaux captured the [[The double|league and league cup double]] and Gourcuff attained several individuals honours, he signed with the club permanently.<ref name="Yoann Gourcuff a signÃ©">{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff signs permanent deal at Bordeaux |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=650557&sec=europe&cc=5739 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=28 May 2009 |accessdate=28 February 2011 }}</ref> Gourcuff is a former winner of the [[UNFP]] Ligue 1 [[TrophÃ©es UNFP du football#Player of the Year|Player of the Year]] award and, in December 2009, was named the [[France Football#French player of the year|French Player of the Year]] for the 2009 calendar year.<ref name="unfp.org">{{Cite news|title=Dix-huitiÃ¨mes TrophÃ©es UNFP du football Saison 2008â2009 Le palmarÃ¨s |url=http://www.unfp.org/site/page.php?id_rubrique=2059&id_langue=1|work=[[UNFP|National Union of Professional Footballers]]|date=23 May 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> In August 2010, he joined [[Olympique Lyonnais]] on a five-year contract.
Gourcuff is a [[France national football team|French international]]. Prior to playing at senior level, he played on the [[France national under-19 football team|under-19 team]] that won the [[2005 European Under-19 Football Championship]]. Gourcuff made his senior national team debut in August 2008.<ref>{{Cite news|title=GOURCUFF Yoann |url=http://www.fff.fr/servfff/historique/historique_new.php?liste=O&id=GOURCUFF%20Yoann |work=[[French Football Federation]] |date=12 August 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> He scored his first international goal two months later against [[Romania national football team|Romania]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=France v. Romania Match Report |url=http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/europe/matches/round=250471/match=300040874/report.html|work=[[FIFA|FÃ©dÃ©ration Internationale de Football Association]]|date=11 October 2008 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> Gourcuff made his first major tournament appearance for France at the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]]. Since joining the national team, he has been inserted into the [[playmaker]] role, a position that was vacated and never filled following the retirement of Zidane in 2006.<ref>{{Cite news|title=TACTICAL OVERVIEW: France |url=http://www.360footballnews.com/index.php/teams/france/analysis/7002-tactical-overview-france |work=360 Football News |date=8 June 2010 |accessdate=11 June 2010}}</ref>
== Early and personal life ==
Gourcuff was born on 11 July 1986 in [[Ploemeur]], Morbihan, Brittany to parents Dr. Marine Thalouarn and [[Christian Gourcuff]], both being [[Breton people|Bretons]].<ref name="gourcuff">{{Cite news|title=Yoann Gourcuff voit la vie en bleu |url=http://www.ouest-france.fr/actu/actuDet_-Yoann-Gourcuff-voit-la-vie-en-bleu-_3639-720386_actu.Htm |work=Ouest-France |date=11 October 2008 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> Gourcuff comes from a very athletic family. His mother was a basketball player, his older brother, Erwan, is a competitive swimmer and cyclist, while his father was a former footballer who played for several clubs in such countries as France, Switzerland, and Canada, however, he is best known for his time at [[Stade Rennais F.C.|Rennes]], [[FC Lorient|Lorient]], and [[Le Mans Football Club|Le Mans]]. Gourcuff's father later moved into the managerial role having stints at Rennes, Le Mans, Lorient (twice), and [[Qatar]]i club [[Al-Gharafa Sports Club|Al-Gharafa]]. He currently serves as manager of Lorient, his third stint at the club, whom he has managed since 2003.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff, Christian|url=http://www.fclweb.fr/equipe/staff/index.php?id=5|work=[[FC Lorient]] |date=12 August 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071016000357/http://www.fclweb.fr/equipe/staff/index.php?id=5 |archivedate = 16 October 2007}}</ref> As a youth, the younger Gourcuff excelled at both football and tennis, becoming the top player of his age group (12), but eventually opted to focus on football.<ref name="gourcuff"/><ref name="maxifoot">{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff, prÃ©nom Yohan|url=http://www.maxifoot.fr/articles/2504/index.htm|work=MaxiFoot |date=1 December 2005 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> While beginning his career as a football player, Gourcuff admired and drew inspiration from the playing style of the [[Brazil national football team|Brazil national team]] from the 1970s, whom he discovered from watching tapes with his father. He often attempted to emulate the skills of Brazilian legend [[PelÃ©]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Interview CroisÃ©e: Yoann et Christian GOURCUFF |url=http://www.footcitoyen.org/?p=456 |work=Foot Citoyen Magazine |date = December 2008|accessdate=27 August 2010| language = French}}</ref>
== Club career == === Early career and Rennes ===
Gourcuff began his career with [[FC Lorient|Lorient]], who were, at the time, managed by his father in 1992. During his time at Lorient, he also trained at [[PEF Ploufragan]], a regional academy located in the [[Brittany (administrative region)|Brittany region]] that trained players similarly to the [[Clairefontaine]] academy in the [[Ãle-de-France (region)|Ãle-de-France]].<ref name="maxifoot"/> Further to his father's departure to [[Stade Rennais F.C.|Stade Rennais]], Gourcuff, who initially considered [[Derby Breton|rivals]] [[FC Nantes|Nantes]], followed suit and signed an ''aspirant'' (youth) contract with the club in 2001.<ref name="maxifoot"/> He spent two years in the club's youth academy and, while competing domestically in the system, Gourcuff played on the club's under-19 team that won the 2003 edition of the [[Coupe Gambardella]]. Rennes defeated [[RC Strasbourg|Strasbourg]] 4â1 in the final match at the [[Stade de France]]. Gourcuff scored the club's opening goal.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Retour en images sur la victoire des Rennais |url=http://www.fff.fr/coup/gambardella/actualite/55102.shtml |work=[[French Football Federation]] |date = 2 June 2003 |accessdate=28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Included on that team with Gourcuff were future club and international teammates [[Jimmy Briand]] and [[Sylvain Marveaux]].
Ahead of the [[2003â04 Ligue 1|2003â04 season]]. Gourcuff was promoted to the club's reserve team in the [[Championnat de France amateur]], the fourth level of [[Football in France|French football]], Gourcuff appeared in 15 matches and scored two goals with the team before signing his first professional contract in November 2003, which resulted in his promotion to the senior team by manager [[Laszlo BÃ¶lÃ¶ni]].<ref name="maxifoot"/><ref>{{Cite news|title=Stade Rennais Reserve Pro: Saison Football 2003/2004 |url=http://www.stat2foot.com/qrclubs/rennes20304.htm |work=Stat 2 Foot |date = |accessdate=28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Gourcuff made his professional debut on 25 January 2004 in a 2â0 victory to [[Ãvian Thonon Gaillard FC|Croix-de-Savoie]] in the [[Coupe de France]] appearing as a substitute. On 7 February, he made his league debut in a 2â0 defeat to [[AJ Auxerre|Auxerre]] appearing as a substitute.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Rennes v. Auxerre Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/48232|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=7 February 2004 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> Following the match, he was relegated back to the reserve team. Gourcuff returned to the senior team in late March making two more substitute appearances against Strasbourg and [[Lille OSC|Lille]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Strasbourg v. Rennes Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/48288|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=27 March 2004 |accessdate=28 February 2011| language = French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Lille v. Rennes Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/48291|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=3 April 2004 |accessdate=28 February 2011| language = French}}</ref> On 18 April, he made his first professional start in a 3â1 win over [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Rennes v. Bordeaux Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/48303|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=18 April 2004 |accessdate=28 February 2011| language = French}}</ref> Gourcuff made his second career start on the final match day of the season assisting on a goal in a 4â0 victory over [[Montpellier HSC|Montpellier]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Rennes v. Montpellier Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/48354|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=23 May 2004 |accessdate=28 February 2011| language = French}}</ref>
For the [[2004â05 Ligue 1|second consecutive season]] under BÃ¶lÃ¶ni, Gourcuff rotated between the club's reserve team and the senior team. He appeared in nine matches with the reserve team and 21 with the senior team.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Stade Rennais Reserve Pro: Saison Football 2004/2005 |url=http://www.stat2foot.com/qrclubs/rennes20405.htm |work=Stat 2 Foot |date = |accessdate=28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Gourcuff only started six matches with the latter team scoring no goals and providing one assist.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Stade Rennais: Saison Football 2004/2005 |url=http://www.stat2foot.com/qrclubs/rennes0405.htm |work=Stat 2 Foot |date = |accessdate=28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In the [[2005â06 Ligue 1|2005â06 season]], he was re-assigned the number 10 shirt by BÃ¶lÃ¶ni and giving a starting place within the team. In his first season as a starter, Gourcuff appeared in 42 total matches and scored six goals. He formed midfield partnerships with fellow Frenchman [[Olivier Monterrubio]] and the [[Sweden|Swede]] [[Kim KÃ¤llstrÃ¶m]] and made his [[UEFA|European]] debut on 15 September in a [[UEFA Cup]] first round tie against Spanish club [[CA Osasuna|Osasuna]] appearing as a substitute.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/uefacup/history/season=2005/round=2208/match=81818/index.html |title = Rennes 3â1 Osasuna |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=15 September 2005 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> Rennes won the tie 3â1 on aggregate and were later eliminated in the group stage portion of the competition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/uefacup/history/season=2005/round=2208/match=81819/index.html |title = Rennes stand firm in Spain |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=29 September 2005 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> Three days after his European debut, on 18 September, Gourcuff scored his first professional goal against [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]] in a 2â0 win.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Monaco v. Rennes Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/49998|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=18 September 2005 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> In November, Gourcuff scored goals in back-to-back matches against [[Troyes AC|Troyes]] and [[Toulouse FC|Toulouse]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Troyes v. Rennes Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/49795|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=6 November 2005 |accessdate=28 February 2011| language = French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Rennes v. Toulouse Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/50016|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=20 November 2005 |accessdate=28 February 2011| language = French}}</ref> In the latter part of the season, Gourcuff went on a scoring run netting three goals in a span of four weeks. He scored the first of these goals on 25 February 2006 in a 4â1 away win over [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Lyon v. Rennes Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/49901|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=25 February 2006 |accessdate=28 February 2011| language = French}}</ref> After going a week without a goal, Gourcuff responded by scoring goals in back-to-back weeks in wins over [[AC Ajaccio|Ajaccio]] and [[FC Metz|Metz]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Rennes v. Ajaccio Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/49921|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=4 March 2006 |accessdate=28 February 2011| language = French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Metz v. Rennes Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/49926|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=11 March 2006 |accessdate=28 February 2011| language = French}}</ref> In the [[Coupe de France]], Gourcuff appeared in all four of the team's matches as Rennes reached the semi-finals where the club was defeated 3â0 by [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]]. Rennes ultimately finished the season in 7th place in the league, which resulted in the club qualifying for the [[UEFA Intertoto Cup 2006|2006 UEFA Intertoto Cup]]. Gourcuff finished his Rennes career with 80 appearances, six goals, and nine assists.
=== Milan ===
Following the season, Gourcuff was linked to a host of big name European clubs such as [[Netherlands|Dutch]] club [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]], Spanish club [[Valencia CF|Valencia]], and English club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. He ultimately joined [[Italy|Italian]] club [[A.C. Milan|Milan]].<ref name="maxifoot"/> He signed a five-year contract with â¬4.58 million transfer fee <ref name="monstersandcritics.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bilanciomilan.it/2007/HTML/2006/HTML/PDF/bilancio.pdf|title=AC Milan 2006 Annual Report|date=ca. April 2007|accessdate=24 April 2011|work=AC Milan|language=Italian}}</ref> Gourcuff was assigned the number 20 shirt and made his competitive debut for the ''Rossoneri'' on 9 August 2006 in the club's [[2006â07 UEFA Champions League#Third qualifying round|UEFA Champions League third qualifying round]] tie against [[Serbia]]n club [[Red Star Belgrade]]. He appeared as a substitute in the 81st minute for [[Andrea Pirlo]] as Milan won the match 1â0.<ref>{{Cite news|title=AC Milan 1â0 Crvena Zvezda |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=204813&cc=5901 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=9 August 2006 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref> In his next competitive match with the club against [[Greece|Greek]] outfit [[AEK Athens F.C.|AEK Athens]] in the Champions League group stage, Gourcuff scored his first career goal for the club in a 3â0 win.<ref>{{Cite news|title=AC Milan 3â0 AEK Athens |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=205449&cc=5901 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=23 September 2006 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref> Gourcuff didn't make his [[Serie A]] debut until 20 September playing the entire match in a 1â0 win over [[Ascoli Calcio 1898|Ascoli]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=AC Milan 1â0 Ascoli |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=205700&cc=5901 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=20 September 2006 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> In the ensuing matches, Gourcuff rotated between the starting lineup and the bench and capped the season by scoring in Milan's final match of the Seria A season; a 3â2 defeat to [[Udinese Calcio|Udinese]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=AC Milan 2â3 Udinese |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=206036&cc=5901 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=19 May 2007 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> Despite not appearing in the [[2007 UEFA Champions League Final]], which Milan won, Gourcuff did earn a winner's medal with the club as a result of his participation in the group stage and knockout round matches.
Due to Milan winning the UEFA Champions League, Gourcuff was included in the squads that competed in the [[2007 UEFA Super Cup]] and the [[2007 FIFA Club World Cup]], though he didn't appear in the former match and appeared infrequently in the latter competition.<ref>{{Cite news|title=AC Milan FIFA World Club Cup Squad |url=http://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/clubworldcup/japan2007/teams/team=1907169/index.html |work=[[FIFA|FÃ©dÃ©ration Internationale de Football Association]]|accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref> In the [[2007â08 Serie A]] season, Gourcuff struggled for playing time as he was in direct competition with the [[Brazil national football team|Brazilian international]] and [[2007 FIFA World Player of the Year]] winner [[KakÃ¡]]. Gourcuff's development and attitude at the club was also questioned by manager [[Carlo Ancelotti]] who critically stated that the player had psychological issues.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff injury blow |url=http://www.acmilan-online.com/archive/arc8-2006.php |work=AC Milan Online |date=28 August 2006 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Yoann Gourcuff Earning Zidane Comparisons |url=http://www.insidefutbol.com/2009/01/18/yoann-gourcuff-earning-zidane-comparisons/ |work=Inside Futebol |date=18 January 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Ancelotti unsure of Gourcuff return |url=http://www.footballnewsblog.co.uk/italian-serie-a/ancelotti-unsure-of-gourcuff-return/ |work=Football News Blog |date=3 March 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Domenech slams AC Milan boss Ancelotti over Gourcuff criticism |url=http://www.tribalfootball.com/domenech-slams-ac-milan-boss-ancelotti-over-gourcuff-criticism-242065 |work=Tribal Football |date=3 May 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Milan chief: Kaka not for sale in the summer |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=624216&cc=5901 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=3 March 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref> Gourcuff only appeared in 15 league matches for the club starting only four. He scored his only goal of the season on 31 October 2007 in a 5â0 hammering of [[U.C. Sampdoria|Sampdoria]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Sampdoria 2â3 Milan |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=224348&cc=5901 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=31 October 2007 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> On 24 February 2008, after appearing as a half-time substitute, Gourcuff assisted on the game-winning goal scored in the 90th minute by [[Filippo Inzaghi]] in Milan's 2â1 win over [[U.S. CittÃ di Palermo|Palermo]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Milan 2â1 Palermo |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=224361&cc=5901 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=24 February 2008 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> In the final nine matches of the season, Gourcuff was an unused substitute in seven of them. In Gourcuff's final match at the club, he asssisted on the final goal by [[Alexandre Pato]] in the club 5â1 win over [[Reggina Calcio|Reggina]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Milan 5â1 Palermo |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=224692&cc=5901 |work=[[ESPN]] |date=20 April 2008 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref>
{{Quote box | width=30% | align=left | quote= "Gourcuff in [[Milan]] was 100% wrong. His problem here was his behavior. He was not intelligent in the manner of managing himself. When he played here, he did not want to make himself available to the group. He did not start to study Italian immediately." |source= <small>Former [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] [[Captain (association football)|captain]] [[Paolo Maldini]] reflecting back on Gourcuff's stint at Milan.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Maldini allume Gourcuff |url=http://www.lequipe.fr/Football/breves2010/20101126_091302_maldini-gourcuff-pas-intelligent.html |work=[[L'Equipe]]|date=26 November 2010 |accessdate=26 November 2010 | language = French}}</ref> </small> }}
Following the season, on 31 May 2008, Milan [[vice-president]] [[Adriano Galliani]] revealed that the club would loan Gourcuff to French club [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]] for the entire [[2008â09 Ligue 1|2008â09 season]] to allow him more playing time.<ref name="m.espn.go.com"/> In 2010, in an interview with French newspaper [[L'Equipe]], former Milan [[Captain (association football)|captain]] [[Paolo Maldini]] stated that Gourcuff lacked discipline while at the club and often distant himself from the team citing the player's refusal to learn the [[Italian language]]. Maldini also stated that Gourcuff did not give his all during his stint at Milan and that the player himself knew it.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Maldini duro su Gourcuff |url=http://www.sportmediaset.mediaset.it/calcio/articoli/articolo47908.shtml |work=Sportmediaset |date=26 November 2010 |accessdate=26 November 2010 | language = Italian}}</ref> Gourcuff did not respond to the comments, but his father, Christian, did stating to [[France Football]] that there was some sort of conspiracy out there looking to tarnish his son's image. The elder Gourcuff responded to Maldini's charges stating his son "took two hours (of Italian language courses) per day and spoke Italian after two months" and that "he is passionate about tactics" in response to Maldini saying Gourcuff refused to learn Italian and he was limited tactically.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Affaire Gourcuff â Maldini: Christian Gourcuff parle de complot autour de son fils |url=http://fr.sports.yahoo.com/07122010/79/07122010150028.html |publisher=Yahoo!|date=7 December 2010 |accessdate=28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Gourcuff was also defended by his club president [[Jean-Louis Triaud]] at his former club Bordeaux who stated in response to Maldini's comments "Yoann is not like that. A number ten who does not play with the group is a little weird. This does not correspond at all to what we saw with Yoann at Bordeaux. He was well integrated with his teammates, and collectively with them on the ground. He left good memories here."<ref>{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff pÃ¨re rÃ©pond Ã Maldini |url=http://www.maxifoot.fr/football/article-11111.htm |work=Maxifoot |date=28 November 2010 |accessdate=28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref>
=== Bordeaux ===
{{Quote box | width=30% | align=right | quote= "That goal was no accident." "It showed there was something magical about him. I felt ill when Zidane retired. Watching Gourcuff has cured me. When I see players like him, I feel like a small boy again." |source= <small>[[Christophe Dugarry]], on Gourcuff's goal against [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|PSG]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/yoann-gourcuff-the-new-zidane-1516832.html|title=Yoann Gourcuff: The new Zidane? |work=The Independent |location=UK|date=29 January 2009|accessdate=11 August 2009}}</ref> </small> }}
At Bordeaux, Gourcuff quickly asserted himself into the squad for the [[2008â09 Ligue 1|2008â09 season]] scoring on his league debut against [[SM Caen|Caen]] in a 2â1 victory and also helping Bordeaux capture their 2nd [[2008 TrophÃ©e des Champions|TrophÃ©e des champions]] title.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Bordeaux v. Caen Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/52258|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=9 August 2008 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> He scored Bordeaux's 4<sup>th</sup> and final goal in the team's 4â0 triumph over [[Vannes OC|Vannes]] in the [[2008-09 Coupe de la Ligue|Coupe de la Ligue]] [[Coupe de la Ligue Final 2009|final]]. Gourcuff also provided the assist on the third goal. He scored two goals in Bordeaux's [[2008â09 UEFA Champions League|Champions League campaign]] against [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] and [[CFR Cluj]]. On 11 January 2009, Gourcuff scored a goal that was voted the goal of the season by fans against [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] in a 4â0 victory.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Bordeaux v. PSG Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/52393|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=11 January 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> Upon receiving the ball from teammate [[Matthieu ChalmÃ©]], just outside of the box, Gourcuff performed a swift ''[[Marseille turn]]'', eluding PSG defender [[Sylvain Armand]], followed by quickly shifting the ball from his right foot to his left causing [[Sammy TraorÃ©]] to lose balance, before bringing the ball back to his right foot and blasting it past Paris Saint-Germain [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] [[MickaÃ«l Landreau]] with the outside of his right foot.<ref name="youtube.com">{{Cite news|title=Yoann Gourcuff Vs PSG â Chef d'oeuvre |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dI0--mM7Ue4|publisher=YouTube |date=14 January 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref>
[[File:Yoann Gourcuff.jpg|thumb|100px|left|Gourcuff in 2008]]
The following two weeks, Gourcuff scored his fifth and sixth goals, respectively, against [[FC Nantes|Nantes]] in a 2â1 victory and [[Lille OSC|Lille]] in a 2â2 draw.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Nantes v. Bordeaux Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/52404|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=17 January 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Bordeaux v. Lille Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/52410|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=24 January 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> After going goalless in the league for seven straight weeks, Gourcuff got back on track scoring against relegation-bound [[Le Havre AC|Le Havre]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Le Havre v. Bordeaux Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/52550|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=21 March 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> On 20 April 2009, Gourcuff scored his first career double against his former club Rennes in a 3â2 victory.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Rennes v. Bordeaux Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/52213|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]]|date=29 April 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> In the ensuing three weeks, Gourcuff maintained his form scoring in all three matches, against [[FC Sochaux-MontbÃ©liard|Sochaux]], [[Valenciennes FC|Valenciennes]], and [[Le Mans Union Club 72|Le Mans]] giving him a tally of 12 league goals for the season.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Bordeaux v. Sochaux Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/52496|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=3 May 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Valenciennes v. Bordeaux Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/52514|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=13 May 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Bordeaux v. Le Mans Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/52520|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=16 May 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> Bordeaux won all three matches, which effectively put them in first place position heading into the final week of the season. Bordeaux eventually won the league capturing the sixth title in the club's history. The club also recorded its second ever [[The Double|double]], as a result of its [[Coupe de la Ligue]] title. For his efforts during the 2008â09 season, Gourcuff was awarded the UNFP Ligue 1 [[TrophÃ©es UNFP du football#Player of the Year|Player of the Year]] award. He was also named in the organization's Ligue 1 [[TrophÃ©es UNFP du football#2009|Team of the Year]].<ref name="unfp.org"/> His performances during the 2008â09 season later earned him a nomination by the French magazine [[France Football]] for the [[Ballon d'Or 2009|2009 Ballon d'Or]] award, won by [[Lionel Messi]] as Gourcuff finished in 20th place with six points.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Ronaldo heads 30 nominations for Ballon d'Or |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SPORT/football/10/18/football.ronaldo.ballon.dor/index.html |publisher=Cable News Network |date=18 October 2009 |accessdate=11 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Ballon d'Or, les Bleus Ã la traÃ®ne |url=http://www.europe1.fr/Sport/Articles/Ballon-d-Or-les-Bleus-a-la-traine-88855/ |work=Europe 1 |date=30 November 2009 |accessdate=28 February 2011| language = French}}</ref>
Due to Gourcuff's impressive season, his parent club announced that it would be open to the player returning to [[Milan]] for the 2009â10 season. However, the club's plans were put on halt after learning of Bordeaux's intent to meet Gourcuff's buy-out clause of â¬15 million included in the loan deal. Despite [[general manager]] [[Adriano Galliani]] and new manager [[Leonardo AraÃºjo|Leonardo]]'s efforts to persuade Gourcuff to return, on 28 May, it was announced that Bordeaux had signed Gourcuff permanently from Milan with Gourcuff agreeing to a four-year deal.<ref name="Yoann Gourcuff a signÃ©"/><ref>{{Cite news|title=Milanâs Adriano Galliani Bemoans Gourcuff Sale |url=http://footballdirecta.wordpress.com/2009/05/30/milans-adriano-galliani-bemoans-gourcuff-sale/|work=Football Directa|date=30 May 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff signs for Bordeaux |url=http://www.channel4.com/sport/football_italia/may28m.html|work=Channel 4 Italia|date=28 May 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080530222127/http://www.channel4.com/sport/football_italia/may28m.html |archivedate = 30 May 2008}}</ref> The transfer fee was â¬13.6 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://media3.acmilan.com/uploads/bilancio/BilancioGruppoMilan_ACM_12-09.pdf|title=AC Milan Group 2009 annual report|accessdate=5 August 2011|work=AC Milan}}</ref>
[[File:Yoann Gourcuff 2009.jpg|thumb|100px|right|Gourcuff during an August 2009 training session]]
Gourcuff began the [[Ligue 1 2009â10|2009â10 season]] claiming his fourth silverware with Bordeaux on 25 July 2009, winning the [[2009 TrophÃ©e des Champions]] title in a 2â0 victory over [[En Avant de Guingamp|Guingamp]]. As a result of his performance, he was named [[Man of the Match]]. Two weeks later, he scored a double in the club's opening match of the league season against [[RC Lens|Lens]]. The final result was 4â1.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Bordeaux v. Lens Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/44991 |work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=9 August 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> The victory set a record in league play for most consecutive wins for the club with 12.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Record pour Bordeaux |url=http://www.francefootball.fr/FF/breves2009/20090809_230601_record-pour-bordeaux.html |work=[[France Football]] |date=9 August 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> On 23 August, he scored another set of goals, this time against [[OGC Nice|Nice]] in a 4â0 victory.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Bordeaux v. Nice Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/44982 |work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=23 August 2009 |accessdate=21 December 2009| language = French}}</ref>
In the [[UEFA Champions League]], Gourcuff assisted on Bordeaux's only goal in the club's opening 1â1 draw against Italian club [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] scored by [[Jaroslav PlaÅ¡il]]. On 30 September, Gourcuff suffered a groin injury in the club's 1â0 victory over [[Israel]]i club [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]], which forced him to miss two league matches and an international call up.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Yoann Gourcuff out of France squad due to thigh injury |url=http://article.wn.com/view/2009/10/01/Yoann_Gourcuff_out_of_France_squad_due_to_thigh_injury_Socce/ |work=World News |date=1 October 2009 |accessdate=21 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Ciani beats clock to clinch Bordeaux win |url=http://www.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/fixturesresults/round=2000028/match=2000381/index.html |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=30 September 2009 |accessdate=21 December 2009}}</ref> Bordeaux lost both matches. He returned to the team for Bordeaux's back-to-back matches with German club [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]. In the first match, which Bordeaux won 2â1, Gourcuff missed a [[Penalty kick|penalty]] after attempting to cheekily chip the ball over [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] [[Hans-JÃ¶rg Butt]], however in the second match, he made amends scoring the [[game winning goal]] in Bordeaux's 2â0 victory at the [[Allianz Arena]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Ciani beats clock to clinch Bordeaux win |url=http://www.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/fixturesresults/round=2000028/match=2000396/index.html |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=21 October 2009 |accessdate=21 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Late shows put Bordeaux through |url=http://www.uefa.com/competitions/ucl/fixturesresults/round=2000028/match=2000420/index.html |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=3 November 2009 |accessdate=21 December 2009}}</ref> Bordeaux eventually finished the group stage portion undefeated.
For most of November and the early part of December, Gourcuff suffered a dip in form in league play going scoreless and also not providing any assists. Manager [[Laurent Blanc]] later stated that Gourcuff had lacked confidence since returning from his injury following Gourcuff's second penalty miss of the season in the club's midweek 1â0 victory over [[Montpellier HSC|Montpellier]] on 16 November.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Bordeaux Star Yoann Gourcuff Is Lacking Confidence â Laurent Blanc |url=http://sports.yahoo.com/soccer/news?slug=goal_bordeaux_star_yoann&prov=goal&type=lgns&print=1 |work=[[Yahoo! Sports]] |date=16 December 2009 |accessdate=21 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Montpellier v. Bordeaux Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/44733 |work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |date=16 December 2009 |accessdate=21 December 2009| language = French}}</ref> However, three days later, Gourcuff returned to form scoring a goal and providing the assists on the other three goals in Bordeaux's 4â1 win over [[FC Lorient|Lorient]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Bordeaux v. Lorient Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/44785 |work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]]|date=19 December 2009 |accessdate=21 December 2009| language = French}}</ref> On 20 December, he was declared by magazine [[France Football]] the [[France Football#French player of the year|French Player of the Year]] for 2009 beating out the likes of [[Nicolas Anelka]], [[Hugo Lloris]], [[Thierry Henry]], and [[Franck RibÃ©ry]]; the latter having won the award the past two seasons prior.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff et Blanc dÃ©corÃ©s |url=http://www.francefootball.fr/FF/breves2009/20091220_114320_gourcuff-et-blanc-decores.html |work=[[France Football]] |date=20 December 2009 |accessdate=21 December 2009| language = French}}</ref>
[[File:Yoann Gourcuff VS Rennes.jpg|thumb|100px|left|Gourcuff during the 2009â10 season.]]
On 23 February 2010, Gourcuff assisted on Bordeaux's only goal, scored by [[MichaÃ«l Ciani]], in the club's shutout victory away to Greek club [[Olympiacos CFP|Olympiacos]] in the first leg of its [[UEFA Champions League]] knockout round match following his delivery of a powerful and driven free kick into the box that landed at the head of the defenseman.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Ciani puts clinical Bordeaux in charge |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2010/round=2000029/match=2000461/postmatch/report/index.html|work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]]|date=23 February 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> In the second leg, he scored the opening goal in the 5<sup>th</sup> minute converting a [[Direct free kick|free kick]] to put Bordeaux up 2â0 on aggregate.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Bordeaux resist Olympiacos rally |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2010/round=2000029/match=2000473/postmatch/report/index.html|work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=17 March 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> The team won the tie with a 3â1 aggregate scoreline to advance to the quarter-finals where Bordeaux faced league rivals [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]]. In the first leg, which Lyon won 3â1, Gourcuff provided the assist on an away goal scored by [[Marouane Chamakh]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Lisandro double puts Lyon in charge |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2010/round=2000030/match=2000476/postmatch/report/index.html|work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]]|date=30 March 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> In the second leg, Bordeaux recorded a first half goal, but were unable to score another as Lyon advanced to the semi-finals on a 3â2 aggregate scoreline.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Lyon hold firm to oust Bordeaux |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2010/round=2000030/match=2000482/postmatch/report/index.html|work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=7 April 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> On 24 April in a league match against Lorient, Gourcuff endured a recurring groin injury during the early stages of the match. Despite showing signs of injury, Gourcuff remained in the match until the end of the first half.<ref>{{Cite news|title=More misery for champions |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/commentary?id=271312&cc=null&league=FRA.1|work=[[ESPN]]|date=24 April 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> Due to the injury, Gourcuff missed the Bordeaux's final five league matches. The club recorded two wins, one draw, and two losses in the five matches which resulted in Bordeaux failing to qualify for [[UEFA|European competition]] [[2010â11 Ligue 1|next season]].
In the 2010â11 season, Gourcuff appeared in Bordeaux's first three league matches of the season. On 22 August 2010, French media reported that, on the eve of the team's match against [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]], the midfielder had informed Bordeaux officials of his intent to join [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff veut rejoindre l'OL |url=http://www.lequipe.fr/Football/breves2010/20100822_084351_gourcuff-veut-rejoindre-l-ol.html|work=[[L'Equipe]]|date=22 August 2010 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> Gourcuff was, subsequently, relegated to the bench for the match. In his final match with the club, he appeared as a substitute and assisted on the game-winning goal scored by Ciani in [[injury time]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Paris Saint-Germain v. Bordeaux Match Report |url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53667|work=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]]|date=22 August 2010 |accessdate=24 August 2010}}</ref>
=== Lyon ===
[[File:Yoann Gourcuff 2010 - OL.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Gourcuff with Lyon in 2010]]
On 23 August 2010, [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]] confirmed on its website that the club had reached an agreement with Bordeaux for the transfer of Gourcuff. After passing his medical on 25 August, Gourcuff signed a five-year contract with the club for a fee of â¬22 million, to be paid in three installments by 31 December 2012.<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://www.olweb.fr/fr/Accueil/100007/Article/53861/Accord-avec-Bordeaux-pour-le-transfert-de-Yoann-Gourcuff | publisher=[[Olympique Lyonnais]] | title = Accord avec Bordeaux pour le transfert de Yoann Gourcuff |date = 23 August 2010 | accessdate = 23 August 2010 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| url = http://www.francefootball.fr/FF/breves2010/20100823_231331_gourcuff-accord-lyon-bordeaux.html | publisher=[[France Football]] | title = Gourcuff: Accord Lyon-Bordeaux|date = 23 August 2010 | accessdate = 23 August 2010 | language = French}}</ref> Gourcuff selected the number 29 shirt and made his club debut on 28 August in the team's 2â0 defeat to [[FC Lorient|Lorient]]. Gourcuff appeared as a substitute in the match for the injured [[CÃ©sar Delgado]].<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53648 | publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] | title = Lorient v. Lyon Match Report |date = 28 August 2010 | accessdate = 7 October 2010 | language = French}}</ref> On 17 October, he scored his first goal for the Lyon in the club's 3â1 win over Lille.<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53713 | publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] | title = Lyon v. Lille Match Report |date = 17 October 2010 | accessdate = 28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref> In the UEFA Champions League, Gourcuff scored his first goal in the team's 4â3 group stage defeat to [[Portugal|Portuguese]] club [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] on 2 November.<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000118/match=2002876/index.html | publisher=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] | title = CoentrÃ£o inspires Benfica revival |date = 2 November 2010 | accessdate = 28 February 2011 }}</ref> In mid-November, he assisted on game-winning goals in back-to-back weeks against [[OGC Nice|Nice]] and [[RC Lens|Lens]].<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53750 | publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] | title = Lyon v. Nice Match Report |date = 14 November 2010 | accessdate = 28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| url = http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53756 | publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] | title = Lens v. Lyon Match Report |date = 21 November 2010 | accessdate = 28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref>
In early February 2011, Gourcuff admitted that he was "disappointed and frustrated" with his performances with Lyon since joining the club stating ""I expected a lot more of myself" and "It's clear that my attacking contribution is not enough".<ref>{{Cite news| url = http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/04/soccer-france-roundup-idUKLDE7130UM20110204 |agency=Reuters | title = Gourcuff disappointed by Lyon form |date = 4 February 2011 | accessdate = 28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref> Gourcuff also admitted that he was struggling to adapt to the style of manager [[Claude Puel]], though the player later clarified his statements stating that they were misinterpreted.<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://www.lequipe.fr/Football/breves2011/20110205_131239_gourcuff-rectifie-l-interview.html | publisher=[[L'Equipe]] | title = Gourcuff rectifie l'interview |date = 5 February 2011 | accessdate = 28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| url = http://www.sport24.com/football/homes-clubs/lyon/fil-info/gourcuff-evoque-puel-blanc-450581/ | publisher=Sport24 | title = Gourcuff Ã©voque Puel, Blanc |date = 7 February 2011 | accessdate = 28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref> On 18 February 2011, Gourcuff scored his third goal for Lyon in the club's 4â0 win over [[AS Nancy|Nancy]].<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53892 | publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] | title = Lyon v. Nancy Match Report |date = 18 February | accessdate = 28 February 2011 | language = French}}</ref> On 27 April 2011 Gourcuff scored Lyon's third and winning goal in a 3-2 victory against Montpellier in 90th minute, after he came in from the bench 2 minutes earlier. Gourcuff underwent ankle surgery in July 2011 in a bid to heal a niggling ankle complaint.<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=1513044.html | publisher=[[FIFA]] | title = Gourcuff suffers ankle setback |date = 19 September 2011 }}</ref>
== International career == === Youth ===
Gourcuff was [[cap (sports)|capped]] for France at the [[France national youth football team|schoolboy level]] earning his first youth cap with the [[France national under-17 football team|under-17 team]] in a 0â0 draw with [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]] on 18 September 2002. He scored his first goal for the team on 5 February 2003 in a friendly match against the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=La France domine la RÃ©publique TchÃ¨que (1â0)|url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m17ans/44719.shtml |work=[[French Football Federation]] |date=5 February 2003 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> Gourcuff finished the season with the under-17 team accumulating twelve appearances and netting two goals as the squad failed to qualify for the [[2003 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship]]. Gourcuff made only four appearances with [[France national under-18 football team|the under-18 team]] scoring his only goal on 30 October in a 2â2 friendly draw with the [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Score de paritÃ© pour le second rendez-vous (2â2)|url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m18ans/71298.shtml |work=[[French Football Federation]] |date=30 October 2003 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> Gourcuff returned to international level with [[France national under-19 football team|the under-19 team]] and was a part of the winning team at the [[2005 European Under-19 Football Championship]]. Leading up to the tournament, Gourcuff scored goals against [[Armenia national football team|Armenia]] in the first qualifying round and [[Spain national under-19 football team|Spain]] in the Elite round.<ref>{{Cite news|title=France 2â1 Armenia|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under19/history/season=2005/round=1924/match=74129/index.html |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=28 September 2004 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff strike sends France through|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under19/history/season=2005/round=1925/match=79821/index.html |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=16 April 2005 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref> The 1â0 victory over Spain assured France's qualification for the tournament. In the tournament, Gourcuff scored a [[hat-trick]] in a 3â1 victory over [[Norway national football team|Norway]] converting two [[penalty kick]]s and scoring in the run of play.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Gourcuff spot on for France|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under19/history/season=2005/round=1926/match=81129/index.html|work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=20 July 2005 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref> He assisted on two goals in the team's 3â2 semi-final win over [[Germany national youth football team#Germany national under-19 squad|Germany]] and played the entire match in the championship match against [[England national under-19 football team|England]]. France won the match 3â1 giving the nation its sixth under-19 title and Gourcuff his first international honor.<ref>{{Cite news|title=French fightback clinches crown|url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under19/history/season=2005/round=1928/match=81509/index.html|work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=29 July 2005 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref> In total with the under-19 team, Gourcuff featured in 17 matches and scored seven goals.
Gourcuff made his debut for the [[France national under-21 football team|under-21 team]] on 18 May 2006 in a preparatory friendly match for the [[2006 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship]] against [[Croatia national under-21 football team|Croatia]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=La France gagne (1â0)|url=http://www.fff.fr/selections_old/espoirs/espoirs_euro2006/actualite/305016.shtml |work=[[French Football Federation]] |date=18 May 2006 |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> In the tournament, Gourcuff was the team's lone underage player and played in all four of the team's matches as France reached the semi-finals losing in [[extra time]] to the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]]. On 5 September 2006, Gourcuff scored his first under-21 goal in a [[2007 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship]] qualification match against [[Slovenia national under-21 football team|Slovenia]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Les Bleuets qualifiÃ©s pour les barrages |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/espoirs/actualite/320567.shtml |work=[[French Football Federation]] |date=5 September 2006 |accessdate=31 May 2010 | language = French}}</ref> France, however, failed to qualify for the tournament. On 27 March 2007, Gourcuff captained the under-21 team for the first time in a 1â0 defeat to [[Norway national under-21 football team|Norway]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=La NorvÃ¨ge s'impose (1â0) |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/espoirs/actualite/368171.shtml |work=[[French Football Federation]]|date=27 March 2007 |accessdate=31 May 2010| language = French}}</ref> Due to injury, he missed the [[2009 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification play-offs]] against [[Germany national under-21 football team|Germany]]. France lost the tie 2â1 on aggregate. The negative result ended Gourcuff's under-21 career.
=== Senior ===
[[File:Gourcuff coup de pied de coin.jpg|thumb|220px|right|Gourcuff (8), preparing to take a [[corner kick]] for [[France national football team|France]].]]
Gourcuff earned his first call up to the senior team on 11 August 2008 for the team's [[Exhibition match|friendly match]] against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] that was played on 20 August.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Domenech goes for youth against Sweden|url=http://www.blnz.com/news/2008/08/12/Domenech_goes_youth_against_Sweden_2539.html|work=BLNZ |date=11 August 2008 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref> He earned his first cap in that match appearing as a substitute in the 92<sup>nd</sup> minute when France's 3â2 victory had been all but confirmed.<ref>{{Cite news|title=SUEDE 2â3 FRANCE |url=http://www.fff.fr/servfff/historique/match_detail.php?nomatch=705 |work=[[French Football Federation]] |date=20 August 2008 |accessdate=12 August 2009| language = French}}</ref> He scored his first goal for ''Les Bleus'' on 11 October 2008 against [[Romania national football team|Romania]] in a [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification|2010 World Cup qualification match]]. The wonder strike from almost 30 yards out drew the match at 2â2 ensuring France's positioning in the group.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Romania 2â2 France |url=http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/preliminaries/europe/matches/round=250471/match=300040874/report.html |work=[[FIFA|FÃ©dÃ©ration Internationale de Football Association]] |date=11 October 2008 |accessdate=12 August 2009}}</ref> Since the match against [[Serbia national football team|Serbia]], held a month before the match against Romania, manager [[Raymond Domenech]] has installed Gourcuff in the [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfield]] position, just behind the [[Forward (association football)|striker]], a position that some believe has yet to be filled since the retirement of [[Zinedine Zidane]] following the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Yoann Gourcuff, Absolutely "The New Zinedine Zidane" |url=http://www.soccerfiesta.net/yoann-gourcuff-absolutely-the-new-zinedine-zidane/ |work=Soccer Fiesta|date=20 January 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009}} {{Dead link|date=June 2010| bot=DASHBot}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=World Cup 2010 Team Profile: Four players who can make the difference for France |url=http://betting.betfair.com/international-football/world-cup-2010/world-cup-2010-team-profile-four-players-who-can-m-050709.html |work=BetFair|date=5 July 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009}} {{Dead link|date=June 2010| bot=DASHBot}}</ref> On 30 May, Gourcuff assisted on the equalizing goal scored by [[William Gallas]] in the team's 1â1 draw with [[Tunisia national football team|Tunisia]]. Gourcuff was a member of France's 23-man team that competed in the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]]. On 11 June 2010, Gourcuff made his [[FIFA World Cup]] debut in the team's opening group stage match against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]]. The match ended 0â0 with Gourcuff being substituted out in the second half. Following the match against Uruguay, former international [[Just Fontaine]] stated that Gourcuff "was lost" during the match.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lequipe.fr/Football/breves2010/20100613_145706_fontaine-tacle-ribery-et-anelka.html |title = Fontaine tacle RibÃ©ry et Anelka |work=[[L'Equipe]] |date=13 June 2010 |accessdate=13 July 2010 | language = French}}</ref> It was later reported by the media that midfielder [[Franck RibÃ©ry]] and striker [[Nicolas Anelka]] had purposely "froze-out" Gourcuff in the Uruguay match.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0623/1224273110084.html |title = Resentment over Gourcuff treatment behind implosion |work=The Irish Times |date=23 June 2010 |accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Sports/Events-Tournaments/FIFA-World-Cup/Top-stories/Yoann-Gourcuff-enigma-clouds-French-camp/articleshow/6048977.cms |title = Yoann Gourcuff enigma clouds French camp |work=The Times of India |date=13 June 2010 |accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref> In the team's final group stage match against the hosts [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]], Gourcuff was sent off in the first half after the referee ruled that he intentionally elbowed an opposing player in the face. France lost the match 2â1, which resulted in its elimination from the competition.
Due to his red card suspension in the World Cup, Gourcuff missed two call-ups to the national team in August and September. In October 2010, he was called back into the team by his former manager at Bordeaux [[Laurent Blanc]] for [[UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying]] matches against [[Romania national football team|Romania]] and [[Luxembourg national football team|Luxembourg]]. In the match against Romania, Gourcuff appeared as a substitute and scored the final goal in the team's 2â0 victory.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro2012/matches/season=2012/round=15171/match=2002080/index.html |title = Substitutes edge France past Romania |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=9 October 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2010}}</ref> He was inserted into the starting lineup against Luxembourg and responded by assisting on the opening goal scored by [[Karim Benzema]] and scoring the second goal in another 2â0 win.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro2012/matches/season=2012/round=15171/match=2002084/index.html |title = Benzema and Gourcuff keep France flying |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=12 October 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://football.uk.reuters.com/leagues/euro2012/news/2010/10/12/LDE69B2DH.php |title = Gourcuff shines as France beat Luxembourg 2â0 |work=[[Rueters]] |date=12 October 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2010}}</ref>
